Award.AwardTitle: Resolving the Structure of Turbulence in Rough Wall Channel Flows Using 3D, Time Resolved, Multiscale Velocity Measurements

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Katz, Joseph
Proposal Number: 1438203

The proposed research aims to explore how turbulence is generated and sustained close to solid boundaries. It will use findings from very accurate experiments to clarify the way that energy is transferred in turbulent flows between the different regions of the flow. As such, this research would allow the development of correct models for the design of flow systems where solid walls are present, which are in fact the most common cases of turbulent flows in industry and the environment. Educational activities involve graduate and undergraduate students for the development and implementation of the proposed measurement system. There are also activities planned for Baltimore City high-school students to work yearlong in the PI?s laboratory as part of their required Research Practicum.

This work will investigate how the roughness height, wavelength, spatial arrangement and uniformity, affect the generation of vortices, their evolution in time, their interactions with vortices away from the wall, and impact of these interactions on turbulence statistics. A rather comprehensive and non-trivial experimental approach is proposed: A 3D time-resolved tomographic PIV will resolve small-scale turbulence near the wall, while digital holographic microscopy (DHM) will be used to simultaneously observe the large scale structures away from the wall. The combined TPIV-DHM instrument would resolve 3.5 orders of magnitude of length scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The objective of this project has been to characterize the flow in the inner part of rough wall boundary layers. The roughness alters the near-wall flow dynamics, increases the drag force, and affects the generation of noise. Yet, owing to the small scales involved, very little is known how the flow interacts with the roughness elements, creating a knowledge gap for scientists and engineers attempting to predict the impact of these interactions. Very few means have exited to measure the flow around the small roughness elements, and owing to the high Reynolds numbers involved, it cannot be resolved computationally. The goals this project has been to introduce new three dimensional measurement technique capable of resolving the flow around the roughness elements, and then use it for quantifying the impacts of interactions among wake structures behind and around roughness elements on the near wall turbulence and energy fluxes. Another objective has been to study the effects spacing between roughness elements on these interactions and fluxes. 

While we thought originally that previously-available holographic microscopy systems could be used for the planned measurements, early attempts showed that they were not accurate enough for the velocity components aligned with the axis of the laser beam. Hence, it was necessary to introduce new instruments and methodology to perform the planned three-dimensional velocity measurements. The new procedure, microscopic dual-view tomographic holography (M-DTH) has been developed, calibrated and implemented. It involved development of self-calibration procedures for precise pairing of elongated traces of the same particle in the two inclined reconstructed fields. Detailed analysis involving synthetic particle showed that the self-calibration method achieved a 3D uncertainty of about 1 micron, a third of the particle diameter. Once the two views were matched, multiplying the corrected intensity fields was used for truncating intersecting elongated particle traces, and finding the precise locations of their centers. Application of this method for 3D velocity measurements was based on the centroids of the truncated/shortened particle traces. After undergoing a series of tests, the new procedures were used for measuring the flow and turbulence around the roughness elements. To the best of our knowledge, M-DTH is the only presently-available technique capable for measuring the three dimensional motion of particles located in dense suspensions at a micron resolution. Related work is still on-going. 

 

Broader impact: High precision three dimensional imaging of dynamic systems has a broad range of applications involving e.g. swimming behavior of marine organisms and bacteria as well as flight behavior of insects. As part of the present effort, we have collaborated with colleagues in the School of Medicine to develop and implement a cinematic digital holography system (400 frames/s) for measuring the impact of genetic modifications to their muscles on their 3D flight behavior. Single view holography was still accurate enough for this purpose. Theflies were released from the bottom of a transparent acrylic enclosure, and a halogen lamp anchored above the chamber enticed then to fly upward. We measured the time history of velocity, acceleration, angular velocity, and radius of curvature of the flight trajectories. Statistical analysis of the results showed that mutants were systematically characterized by lower acceleration over the length of their flight paths. In addition to the specific results, these tests introduced a convenient procedure that could be used for evaluating the impact of other genetic interventions on macroscopic behavior of organisms.
